description: From Middle English ynkhorn, inkehorn (“small portable vessel, originally made of horn, used to hold ink”), equivalent to ink +‎ horn. Displaced Old English blæchorn, which had the same literal meaning but with the native term for "ink."

entries.meaning: (archaic) A small portable container, often made of horn, used to carry ink.
(used attributively, derogatory, of vocabulary) Pedantic, obscurely scholarly.
